Quoting Brian Denny <brian@...>:

> J.B. Rainsberger wrote:
> <snip>
> > JUnit is not a codepath analysis tool; it is a tool for expressing
> black-box
> > tests at the class level.
> </snip>
> 
> okay, i'm confused about "black box" and "white box" testing.
> 
> i've heard a couple of people say that JUnit is a tool for "black box"
> testing (at the class/method/"unit") level.  i even think Kent Beck
> said
> something to that effect in the TDD book.
> 
> but I think i've heard other people refer to "unit testing" and "white
> box
> testing" as though they were synonyms.

I don't believe they are synonyms. I'm sure that everyone will correct me if 
I'm wrong, but a white-box test uses knowledge about the implementation of a 
thing to test the thing. A black-box test only uses observable behavior to test 
the thing.

Therefore,

If I test a template method by asserting that it calls four methods in a 
certain sequence, that's a white-box test.

If I merely assert that foo(3) answers 6 and foo(4) answers 12, that's a black-
box test.

Good test suites are composed of black-box tests at the appropriate levels. 
These test suites are more refactoring-friendly. White-box tests have a 
tendency to get in the way when the production code has to change.

> I'm particularly confused about the following example:
> 
> Let's say that I'm testing some code that exercises a database.  So i
> create
> a MockStatement and say "ms.setExpectedUpdateCalls(3)", or something to
> that
> effect, and pass it in to my object.
> 
> In my view, this is tantamount to designing a "probe" which will fit
> through
> one of the holes in the box (ie conforms to the public interface),
> thereby
> allowing us to snoop on what is happening inside the box.... Now, maybe
> i'm
> just misunderstanding the terminology, but my gut tells me that this
> should
> not count as "black box" testing.

I see this particular case as a low-cost substitute for a black-box test. The 
black-box test would probably check that the updates happened as expected in 
the database. By doing so, the test does not worry about how that happens. In 
the example you provide, the tester asserts instead that the code tries to 
update three tables. The assumption is that they're the right three tables, I 
guess. This test assumes that SQL interface to the database works as expected, 
since there's no point in testing the database.

Is this a white-box or a black-box test? I guess it's white-box, because it 
assumes that the production code needs to perform three SQL updates, which is 
an assumption about the implementation.

But, of course, since we're only testing through the public interface, it's 
black-box testing by definition: "Tests that only use observable behavior." The 
public interface *is* the observable behavior. (Well, not exactly, but it's 
less wordy than the exact facts.)

JUnit is probably best used for black-box testing, but we're all pragmatic 
here: sometimes a white-box test is the way to go. JUnit lets you do both.
